intro: Ophrys fusca subsp. akhdarensis, commonly known as the Akhdar Mountains bee orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to the mountainous regions of the Eastern Mediterranean. It is characterized by its intricate floral structure, which mimics the appearance of a female bee to attract male bees for pollination. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils at high altitudes, where it thrives in cool, humid microclimates. Its flowers are usually dark brown to black in color, with a distinctive bee-like face and intricate patterns. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, requiring conservation efforts to protect its natural environment.
